node.title: These students got together to talk about suicide prevention. The results could help others across Australia
node.alt: Bryndice, Harriet and Abi wearing green formal school jackets adorned with badges, standing together and laughing in a library.
node.description: There are promising signs a suicide prevention program, being trialled in certain high schools, could help to reduce suicidal thoughts and behaviours of students.
node.content:
["There are promising signs a suicide prevention program\u00a0being trialled in certain high schools\u00a0could help reduce suicidal thoughts and behaviours in\u00a0students.", "The Youth Aware of Mental Health (YAM) program, run by the Black Dog Institute and the NSW Education Department, has been trialled in 18 schools across the state.", "\"It was student led [and] it was engaging,\" year 10 student\u00a0Harriet Kingham,\u00a0from Asquith Girls High School in Sydney's upper north shore, said.", "\"There were open discussions and it was just a really comfortable environment to be in and talk about really serious issues that were relevant to us.\"", "The program is run by experts external to the school, something Harriet says helped her feel more at ease.", "As part of the program, students are broken up into small groups\u00a0and raise issues they want to discuss. Some of the most common ones are bullying, peer pressure, and problems at home.", "They then role play\u00a0those issues to think critically about how to deal with certain situations.", "It is also hoped the program will equip the students with the vocabulary they need\u00a0to identify and understand mental illness, and learn when they need to seek help for themselves or someone else.", "The program is not mandatory and students who find the content too overwhelming are able to opt out.", "
Suicidal thoughts and depression ease after program
", "", "
Some students said the experience brought them closer together.(ABC News: Niall Lenihan)
", "Harriet's classmate, Bryndis Pastars, said the experience brought her year group closer together.", "\"We're in an environment where we were sitting in a circle and you could see all the other people and you could see if the questions were affecting them as well. So you would think, 'Oh, OK, so we're kind of in the same boat,'\" she said.", "She said younger people today were facing a unique set of challenges, and figuring out ways to cope with them could\u00a0be complicated.\u00a0", "\"With all of our social media making us more disconnected with each other [and] with the world, we're getting less talkative,\" she said.", "\"It's harder for us to build interpersonal relationships.\"", "Another student who took part in the program, Abi Morgan, used resources provided in the trial to seek further help.\u00a0", "\"I've been talking to someone from Headspace \u2026 about lots of different stressful activities,\" Abi said.", "\"I struggled a lot through lockdown. It was pretty stressful to get through all the schoolwork and [my] motivation was down.\"", "", "
Abi Morgan says the program has helped her cope better with stressful situations.(ABC News: Niall Lenihan)
", "Black Dog Institute psychologist Lauren McGillivray has been overseeing the program, which targets students in years nine\u00a0and 10.", "\"We found that students reported reduced presence of suicidal ideation, less severe depression symptoms, and were more likely to seek help for a personal or emotional problem after receiving the program,\" Dr McGillivray said.", "Students were asked to complete a survey asking if they had experienced suicidal ideation in the two weeks prior to the program beginning. Of those who completed the survey, 51 per cent said they had. The same question was asked six months later, and that figure dropped to 39 per cent.", "Though, Dr McGillivray said the program targeted regions with a higher rate of suicidal behaviour than\u00a0the general population, so it might not be reflective of all people in that age group.", "\"That figure does include passive suicidal thoughts,\" Dr McGillivray said.", "\"So\u00a0the students didn't necessarily have an intent to plan for suicide. But it is still concerning.", "\"There are a lot of surveys and hospital data coming out showing that there's a rapid increase in the 15 to 19-year age group for suicidal thoughts and deliberate self-harm to hospitals compared to younger age. So, this middle age of high school is a really important focus for suicide-prevention efforts.\"", "Results from the trial have been published in the International Journal of Mental Health Systems.", "
The importance of the 'first conversation'
", "Melanie Farrugia, the head teacher of wellbeing at Asquith Girls High School, said while literacy and numeracy would always take centre stage, schools should also be teaching students about self-care.", "\"We live in an ever-changing world; we've gone through a pandemic, we have social media that continues to generate images of reality that aren't quite real,\" she said.", "\"And\u00a0so\u00a0that brings up a lot of questions for our students and we need to teach them that it's OK to talk about things, that it's OK to ask for help, and empower them to support themselves, support their peers, and navigate their way through this period of life.\"", "", "
Melanie Farrugia says it is important to teach students about self-care.(ABC News: Niall Lenihan)
", "Suicide Prevention Australia is calling for more government investment to ensure student-led programs like YAM can be offered to students right across Australia.", "\"There's a lot of evidence that the first time someone has that conversation about suicide or whether they're having thoughts of self-harm is critical,\" Matthew McLean, the director of policy and government relations at Suicide Prevention Australia, said.", "\"It's that first conversation, and more importantly the response to it, that then might determine whether or not that person seeks more professional clinical supports.\"", "And with the end-of-year holidays approaching, he said it was important people continued to ask for help if they needed it.", "\"It's been great to see people reaching out in record numbers for the help and services available. And we hope people continue accessing those important supports right across our community,\" he said."]
